subject: Re: [junit] Will JUnit 'fail()' trip up ALL code coverage tools?
msgSnippet: ... Those are good points. I suppose I /wish/ I were on a project whose worst problem was code coverage in the tests! It s a good goal to go for. -- J. B.

Elliotte Rusty Harold wrote:
> Ilja Preuss wrote:
>  > Why are you testing the coverage of your test code, not just your 
> production
>  > code?
>  >
> 
> Same reason you test any other code: to make sure it's being run. When
> using code coverage tools on test code I've found tests that weren't
> being executed due to incorrect naming conventions, asserts that weren't
> reached due to bad logic, and vestigial code I no longer needed that
> could be deleted. There normally won't be as much untested code in the
> test suite as their is in the main body of code. However there's usually
> some; and, while some of it are fail() statements and the like that you
> don't want to be reached, some of it is significant and requires a repair.

Those are good points. I suppose I /wish/ I were on a project whose 
worst problem was code coverage in the tests! It's a good goal to go for.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
